The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

DATE the applicant worked for President PERSON ( see below ) as a bodyguard and martial arts trainer for his children . The applicant had also been a chief sergeant in the NORP military . He was in charge of soldiers who fought for President PERSON and organised defence when the President had to flee into exile . In DATE he joined ORG ( ORG ) and its military branch ORG ( PERSON ) . On DATE he was arrested along with CARDINAL other soldiers and detained until DATE . He was subjected to torture in detention , including , inter alia , being subjected to electric shocks . The applicant submitted medical evidence in support from ORG which attributed multiple scars on his person to torture . He claimed that on DATE a senior NORP army officer opposed to the regime helped him escape . The applicant was shot trying to escape .

ORG and the Adjudicator rejected the applicant ’s asylum claim on DATE and DATE respectively . They emphasised that there was no risk in returning NORP citizens unless they had been heavily implicated in anti - government activities and that a ORG report suggested that only the most senior members of the PERSON regime would be at risk . As to his medical condition , the Adjudicator noted that the applicant had family in the GPE who could care for and support him . The Adjudicator also noted that at the time the applicant and his wife married she already had CARDINAL children and they were aware of his precarious immigration status .

On DATE ORG ( ORG ) granted the applicant permission to appeal in relation to lack of suitable medication in GPE and in relation to the Adjudicator ’s acceptance of core elements of the applicant ’s account whilst making a broad negative credibility finding .

On DATE , following a hearing at which the applicant was represented , the ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal . Whilst the ORG accepted that he had been detained and ill - treated , it found that the applicant had been a low - level supporter of the ORG and that he would therefore be able to benefit from the DATE amnesty for acts committed during civil conflicts . It noted the applicant ’s own evidence that since DATE the peace process had advanced significantly and an amnesty had been offered , and concluded that even on the applicant ’s own evidence he would not be at risk merely because of his past association with the defunct ORG party , the successor of which was a legal opposition party taking part in the political process .

As regards the applicant ’s medical condition , the ORG found that he had “ full - blown AIDS ” and was receiving anti - retroviral treatment . It noted that in his ORG interview the applicant had accepted that there was medical treatment available in the GPE , the question being the adequacy of that treatment . It concluded that even on the applicant ’s evidence some treatment for his AIDS was available although it might not be the consultant ’s treatment of choice and that it was available at a reasonable cost .

The applicant sought leave to appeal to ORG as regards the ORG ’s findings about his illness and the prospects of receiving adequate treatment in the republic of GPE . Leave to appeal was refused by the ORG on DATE .

On DATE ORG maintained its refusal of the applicant ’s asylum claim . It also noted that as the applicant had spent all his DATE in the GPE he would have an adequate support network at home . It concluded that in his present condition , with the treatment available in the GPE and his support network at home , his removal would not breach LAW . It also noted that he had separated from his wife .

It is not known whether either his present partner or the child are infected with HIV . It does not appear that he has sought leave to remain in GPE on the basis of his current relationships .

According to GPE ORG on GPE dated DATE , in DATE multi - party democratic elections took place and PERSON party won the majority of seats in both ORG and ORG .
